posts.name: Micah Doberne-Schor
posts.cooked: Hi CD, Our team is planning to switch from daisy-chaining to a star can wiring system this offseason. In this setup, each device will have its own can wire route, and a break in the loop does not spell disaster for the entire system when a connection is lost during a match. We’re also wondering if there are good terminals available to split the wire into separate terminals for multiple connections—this would allow the central can wire to branch out and connect to each device in the network. Any recommendations on this would be appreciated. Thanks!

posts.name: Noah
posts.cooked: We used this to split off several connections for our elevator this year. It is a Wago-style Splitter Block.

posts.name: Saber_8871
posts.cooked: We have used WAGO connectors for the past two seasons and they were a godsend when we encountered a CAN fault mid-competition. We also applied Ferrule clamps to the ends of our wires to ensure secure connections, saving the last-minute replacement for the faulty component.

posts.name: Justin
posts.cooked: You're likely to receive many responses divided into two main camps regarding the use of a star topology in CAN networks. One group argues against it, citing issues with network reliability, while another group defends its use, acknowledging that it can work effectively despite not always aligning perfectly with strict CAN documentation guidelines. Teams on CD have successfully implemented custom PCBs to establish a star topology, and if you're considering this approach, I highly recommend seeking insights from them. My background is rooted in standard CAN systems, but I hold no bias toward either topology—I simply advocate for choosing what works best for your team.

posts.name: Graham Howard
posts.cooked: When using a star topology with a Controller Area Network (CAN) setup, you must be highly disciplined regarding stub length. For the CAN 2.0B standard used by the Rio, only 0.3 meters (about 12 inches) is specified. While you may not encounter issues beyond that length, keep in mind that such configurations are technically unsupported. For the CAN FD protocol, as used by the Cross The Road Electronics (CTRE) Canivore, there is no established safe stub length, and using a star topology is not recommended. Instead of dedicating time to troubleshooting a star setup, consider addressing why your CAN bus is failing and working on improvements. Common causes could include connector issues or other related hardware problems.

posts.name: Robin
posts.cooked:
EXTREMELY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH.

Hmm. I don’t have much experience, but I don’t think that’ll work. The CAN standard requires 120Ω terminations on both ends, and having multiple ends might cause unwanted behavior. You can access the full CAN specification here: https://www.ti.com/lit/an/slla270/slla270.pdf, which I’ve mainly drawn from page 7.

Secondly, even with a star topology, there’s always a single point of failure. If the RoboRIO disconnects, you lose all connectivity. With a bus topology, there are more single points of failure, but there will still be at least one.

Now that I think about it, I’m curious about everyone’s thoughts on this topology:

/----------- Device -----------\
RIO ------ | ---------- Device ------------ | -------- PDH
\----------  Device ----------
 

I mean, it has two terminations but relies on unspecified behavior by the CAN standard. And honestly, is it really cursed?

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked: Here we go again. If you just want connectors, I think you should just go for the style AzMaverick suggested, though I would recommend looking for genuine Wagos if your budget allows. If you want more star can information, there are already a few threads out there, some with quite heated discussions about the topic.

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked: Creating loops with different lengths will likely cause interference in communication, so it probably won’t work. I’d be happy to be proven wrong if someone has the chance to test it.

posts.name: Nick Foote
posts.cooked:
I wouldn’t recommend using a star topology but I would suggest considering a trunk and branch topology instead. There’s a detailed discussion about this on our wiring, which might align with what you’re looking for. Here are my key tips:

1. Ensure your main trunk is well-protected. A damaged main trunk can affect reliability if it’s compressed by another robot or snagged by your own mechanisms.  
2. Keep the stubs off the main branch short, including the extensions on the other side of the device. While it feels counterintuitive, one end of the CAN bus on your motors must be significantly shortened.  
3. Invest in high-quality connectors to maintain reliable connections.  
4. Avoid using wago splitters; instead, use an open barrel crimp to securely connect multiple wires when splitting them.

This innovative system reduces the complexity of your setup by consolidating wiring, making it easier to manage and install. Priced at USD 39.99, it offers a reliable and convenient solution for streamlining your robotics project's wiring. Users have reported success with this system, though care is recommended when installing, such as securing Ethernet cables properly after connections are made. The system uses Ethernet cabling as the trunk and Wago connectors for CAN network branches, which worked well for swerve drives and other connections in their robots. They utilized a Canivore for their arm, sticking with the daisy-chaining method.

Or would this only be possible with a second CAN bus (i.e., Canivore)? We would like to try CANnect for our drivetrain in the offseason but would prefer to keep the rest of the bus together.

posts.name: Tauseef Afraz
posts.cooked: If you turn off the resistor, you will have a CAN out port.

posts.name: billjester3
posts.cooked: Rio to Inject to other stuff to Resistor, with (cat5), followed by Direct to Direct to Direct to Direct (loop switch on).

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked:
Daisy chain and star configurations are both used in electrical systems but differ mainly in branch and trunk length. Daisy chains use very short branches, essentially just traces on the PCBs within each device, while stars have longer branches. Wiring a robot with a star topology would require branch lengths exceeding the typical ~12” limit for the Rio’s CAN template, which is why my team avoids using CANivore standards entirely.  

When evaluating reliability, the number of potential failure points matters more than the overall number of failures. Daisy chaining is problematic because the JST PH connectors commonly used for CAN devices are relatively unreliable, and a failure in one part can bring down the entire network. Additionally, using daisy chains means frequent maintenance tasks like replacing a device disrupt the trunk connection. Some CAN wires come with an extra loop designed to prevent damage when unplugging devices, but REV’s approach of jamming two wires, which are often larger than the JST PH connectors are rated for, leads to weak crimps and loose housings, causing poor connections. To avoid this, Thrift uses soldered loops outside the JST connectors, which provides a more secure fit.  

For better reliability, we prefer trunk and branch configurations. This setup allows us to use any connectors for the trunk and ensures proper strain relief, minimizing the need for future maintenance. We rely on Wago 222-413 and 222-415 VHBed connectors for our trunks, finding them highly reliable. For branches, we make custom JST PH pigtails using 24ga mil-spec wire, about 4 inches long, which have held up well without issues since we began manufacturing them ourselves with appropriately sized wire.

posts.name: Tauseef Afraz
posts.cooked: Inject CAN Out connects to other CAN devices, which then connect to a 120-ohm termination resistor. The RIO CAN module connects to an Ethernet injector, which directly interfaces with the Ethernet network, and there's a loopback mechanism activated by a switch. Additionally, there's an internal loopback connection established for testing purposes.

posts.name: billjester3
posts.cooked: Internal loopback in the context of electronics, particularly with Rio connectors, refers to a technique where a signal is routed back into the circuit to facilitate testing and debugging. This method typically involves connecting specific pins on the Rio connectors to create a closed circuit, allowing for the evaluation of signal integrity or functionality without disrupting the primary circuit. On a Rio, this can be achieved through the use of jumper wires, dedicated header pins, or software settings, depending on the specific model. The purpose is to ensure that components and connections work as intended, aiding in the troubleshooting and refinement of electronic designs during the prototyping stage.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: I'm not electrical and might be incorrect. I believe the "eternal loopback" refers to a second pair of wires in the Ethernet cable leading back to the terminator resistor. I'm not sure why the diagram shows it connecting to the RIO.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Pretty sure Wago lever connectors rely on high surface area and compressing the strands, making Fur rules a poor choice. This is a debated topic on this forum…

Not that Fur rules won’t work (they will), but the wires may pull out easier. The resistance in the connection isn’t really an issue with Controller Area Network (CAN) (or any signal wire in FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC)), but may be with power.

By a similar token, twisting the wires after you strip them is poor practice. Again, the connection will work, but it makes the mechanical holding power of the connector and the contact area smaller.

IMO, proper soldering is the most secure option. If that’s not possible, minimize the risks with your chosen connector—for example, using zip ties, proper strain relief, or hot glue.
